title-group.article-title: When media and world politics meet: Crisis press coverage in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts

author-notes.corresp: Hemda Ben-Yehuda, Department of Political Studies, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan 52900, Israel. Email: hemdaby@gmail.com

abstract.p: This study employs crisis press coverage (CPC) to examine the uniform reporting assertion raised in communication theories. To explain CPC, the authors outline and apply a conceptual framework that links crises diversity and reporting modes. Findings on all short crises in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts from 1945 to 2006 show that despite differences in crisis attributes some coverage similarities remained intact, particularly the use of text at the expense of photos and similar issues in the news agenda. Yet, most CPC characteristics support a positive link between crises diversity and variety in press coverage, casting doubt on the single coverage hypothesis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: When media and world politics meet, the press singles out certain events in its coverage of conflict, crisis and war. This study proposes a new concept of crisis press coverage (CPC), outlines a theoretical framework to explain it and explores 14 short crises in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts over six decades to challenge the assertion raised in media literature regarding a uniform reporting mode.

sec.title: Studies on crisis and media
sec.p: Crisis, a core concept in international relations literature, occurs when a major change, restricted time for decision, limited information and uncertainty are coupled with threats to core values at the personal, group, or state levels. Such dramatic situations involve above normal prospects of interstate violence, endanger international stability and attract media attention (Brecher and Ben-Yehuda, 1985; Hermann, 1969). Reporting on crises intensifies when they are part of an ongoing conflict because the dangers of escalation are even greater (Ben-Yehuda and Sandler, 2002; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997; Goertz and Diehl, 1993; Maoz and Mor, 1996). The media convey the breaking news from and to people around the globe and play a crucial role in setting the conflict agenda and framing its reality.

At the juncture of crisis and media, cumulative research has contributed to an understanding of how journalists may affect escalation processes. Studies on the framing of leaders and state behavior in crises explore media coverage of foreign policy moves during various confrontation phases and find that press functions vary (Bloch-Elkon and Lehman-Wilzig, 2007; Garrison, 2007). Research on media in war and conflict shows that rating is gained at the expense of professional coverage and may bring about a rise in tensions (Archetti, 2005; Awabdy et al., 2008; Bennett and Paletz, 1994; Boaz, 2005; Carruthers, 2000; Gilboa, 2008a; Hayes and Guardino, 2010; Höijer et al., 2002; Kalb and Saivetz, 2007; Taylor, 1998; Taylor and Moorcraft, 2008; Wolfsfeld, 2004). Peace journalism focuses on the transition from conflict to peace and points to a pivotal role the media should play in promoting reconciliation processes and peace (Ottosen, 2010; Shinar, 2009; Shinar and Kempf, 2007). The debate on the roles of the media in escalation is clarified further, but left open in the investigations of the CNN and Al Jazeera effects (Gilboa, 2005; Livingston, 2011; Robinson, 2005, 2011; Seib, 2008). Some studies deal with media and policy formation or decision-making processes from a practical standpoint and stress the importance of media management, public diplomacy (Cohen, 1963; Gilboa, 2008b; Naveh, 2002) and crisis communication (Löffelholz, 2009) in order to provide operational guidelines and policy implications.

To explain the role the media plays, agenda setting addresses the mode by which media organs highlight specific topics, disregard others and create a unique news arena (Cohen, 1963; Cottle and Mugdha, 2008; Gudelunas et al., 2002; Iyengar and Simon, 1994; Kiousis and Wu, 2008; McCombs, 1981; McQuail, 1994, 2007; Rogers and Dearing, 2007; Scheufele and Tewksbury, 2007; Soroka, 2003; Weaver, 2007; Weaver et al., 2004). Media coverage also involves framing which transforms events through ‘formats’ that filter and reflect images of reality in world politics. This process involves a struggle over interpretive frames, ideological or value perspectives, story-lines, symbols, and relevant stereotypes (Druckman, 2001; Entman, 1991, 2007; Hallahan, 1999; Iyengar and Simon, 1994; Kolmer and Semetko, 2009; Norris et al., 2003; Roeh and Nir, 1993; Scheufele, 1999; Scheufele and Tewksbury, 2007; Wolfsfeld, 1997, 2011). Together, these theories portray a tightly knit web by which, despite the particulars of each event, common reporting patterns emerge, especially in times of crisis. This uniformity consists of media organs that emphasize certain events at the expense of others and shape the way the conflict is portrayed. When editors follow similar rules regarding relative news value to determine the inclusion of items concerning crisis, conflict or war, homogeneity is further tightened (Galtung and Ruge, 1970; Harcup and O’Neill, 2001; Westerstahl and Johansson, 1994). Framing may add a nuanced look to news contents without abandoning the single reporting mode during crisis.

sec.title: Framework: Crises diversity and crisis press coverage (CPC)
sec.p: This study advances three goals: to introduce the concept of crisis press coverage (CPC), to explore its patterns in short crises and to test the single reporting mode assertion raised in communication studies. The concept of CPC integrates media concepts within a demarcated unit of analysis: an international crisis. CPC is defined as the overall reporting contents, characteristics and modes that typify media coverage during a given crisis. It consists of text and photo items from the outbreak of an international crisis until the end of the confrontation. When the crisis is part of an ongoing conflict, CPC also focuses on the broader context of enduring rivalries related to the crisis events. The importance of CPC stems from the acute nature and high news value of crises. It embodies complex media practices in crucial situations where politics and journalism meet and escalation to violence is imminent. This makes CPC a useful concept in the analysis of the role the media plays in crisis dynamics.

The CPC framework is detailed in Figure 1. In operational terms, CPC is represented by reporting modes, a dependent variable cluster and explained by crises diversity, the independent variable that consists of core crisis attributes.

This study builds on the international crisis behavior (ICB) project for its variables and data on crises in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts. Crises diversity, summarized in Table 1, incorporates seven situational attributes: trigger, gravity of stakes, violence, outcome, duration, system polarity and nonstate actor participation.

sec.p: Reporting mode, the dependent variable cluster, is derived from the media and crisis (MAC) project. It consists of seven variables: coverage days, number of items, item location, headline, item type, issue, and topic. CPC salience denotes the overall exposure an event receives in the media, taking both content and structure elements into account.

The CPC framework is applied to events in two distinct conflicts. It examines two alternative reporting modes during crisis situations: uniform and multiple. The basic hypothesis on the uniform mode, H1, asserts that crises diversity will result in similar press coverage. This claim is deduced from agenda setting and framing theories that place distinct events in common schemes. H2, the rival hypothesis, asserts that high crises diversity will result in a variety of press coverage modes. This claim emphasizes the complex realities of crises and conflicts in world politics that are likely to affect contents, characteristics and modes of media coverage.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: Variables and data from the ICB and the MAC projects serve as the operational and empirical basis for the analysis of CPC in The New York Times (NYT) front page regarding 14 short crises, 7 each in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts (for a description of the MAC project, see Ben-Yehuda et al., 2010).1

The ICB project is a major resource in the study of crisis, conflict and war in international relations. It offers theory, variables, a detailed operational codebook and a wealth of data (Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 2010).2 The MAC project adds the media prism as a vital component to crisis research. It focuses on CPC and crises dynamics in the Arab–Israel, East–West and India–Pakistan conflicts, looking at local and international newspapers.

The Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts are useful critical cases that maximize crises diversity and advance the task of testing H1 and H2 on the link between crises diversity and CPC modes. The investigation looks at all crises that lasted up to 21 days, and includes text items, headlines, photos, and graphics. It addresses 341 front pages, covering a week before the crisis began, all crisis days and a week after each crisis ends.3 Together, 531 relevant news items are the basis for an in-depth content analysis of press narratives, 136 related to the Arab–Israel conflict and 395 to the East-West confrontation.4 The analysis is shaped by the asymmetric nature of available empirical data: the unit of analysis on crisis attributes covers a total of 14 cases, while the press coverage unit amounts to 531 news items. To handle the gap between unequal units, the study adds an assumption regarding the operation of a causal mechanism that transforms crisis diversity into typical but distinct reporting modes. When qualitative and quantitative results show a positive link between dependent and independent variables, the study infers that support for H2 is an empirical conclusion.

sec.title: Crises diversity
sec.p: Table 2 points to diversity in core crisis attributes, within and between conflicts, with the exception of crisis outcome that was usually unilateral in form and non-accommodative in nature. In the Arab–Israel conflict, short crises occurred mostly during the polycentric period of 1963–1989, with only one case each in the bipolar and unipolar eras. Duration varied greatly with more than half of the crises lasting approximately a week and the remaining cases continuing for almost three weeks. Though crisis outbreak usually involved violent triggers with grave damage stakes, violence was highly diverse and split equally between minor and serious clashes. All crises involved the extensive participation of nonstate actors along with state adversaries.

sec.p: Diversity, though different in nature, characterized short crises in the East–West conflict. In all but one case, nonstate actors were absent from the crisis arena. These confrontations took place in bipolar and polycentric systems, almost equally split, and lasted a week or two. The outbreak of these crises varied greatly, with more than half of them triggered by nonviolent events, and covered a broad range of issues, even existence. However, with the exception of one case, all crises contained minor violence or none.

sec.title: CPC in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts
sec.p: The analysis of these two distinct conflict prototypes based on the NYT as a single media platform introduces an additional difference between them. As confrontations in faraway locations, their relevance for prospective readers was not the same and should result in different reporting patterns. For the NYT readers, the East–West confrontation is their own conflict with high global relevance and immediate implications while the Arab–Israel confrontation is a remote conflict among others, with less immediate relevance (Deprez and Raeymaeckers, 2011; Handley and Ismail, 2010; Nossek, 2004; Nossek and Berkowitz, 2006).

sec.title: A uniform CPC
sec.p: In support for H1, the analysis points to CPC similarity with regard to the prominence of text over photos and the dominance of diplomatic and military issues relative to all other matters.

sec.title: Type of news items
sec.p: As indicated in Figure 2, CPC in both conflicts consisted almost entirely of text, 82 percent in the Arab–Israel case and 87 percent in the East–West case. This prevalence of text over photos is not surprising, given the orientation and goals of elite newspapers that specialize in surveillance and correlation, unlike popular media. Yet it is interesting to note that a very similar proportion was found in both conflicts.

caption.p: Type of news items in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.p: Among all crises in both conflicts, the highest concentration of pictures appeared during the 1996 Operation Grapes of Wrath between Israel and Lebanon. Since this crisis is the most recent case in this study, perhaps photo coverage may be attributed to globalization or technological advances which enable and push the media to allocate more front page exposure to photographs and graphics. However, time alone is not the sole determinant because as early as the 1961 Bay of Pigs, and then again in the 1983 Grenada case, close to a third of all news items were photos. Till more empirical data on international crises is generated, the link between the nature of the crisis and the ratio of photos in CPC remains open.

sec.title: Issues
sec.p: Agenda setting captures the main issues in confrontation and portrays them in press narratives. Within the details of unique events and complex story-lines, issues embody core themes and provide a broad perspective for comparisons over time and space. Findings, summarized in Table 3, show that despite crises diversity, more similarity than difference characterized issues both in the headlines and in the text of crisis relevant news items. These findings accord with the agenda setting stipulations on how the media chooses certain issues at the expense of others, to capture attention and gain high rating.

caption.p: Issues in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

fn.p: Chi square: for news item = .001; for headline = .005.

sec.p: Diplomacy was the most important issue in CPC of both conflicts, found in almost half of the news items each. The military–security issue was next, found in 20 percent of the Arab–Israel narratives and 23 percent of the East–West ones. These similarities are striking especially given the violent nature of the former conflict compared to the nonviolent characteristic of the latter. Other issues, with the exception of political/bureaucratic and social ones were addressed with similar coverage in both conflicts. The higher CPC of political/bureaucratic issues in the East–West confrontation was matched by higher coverage of social matters in the Arab–Israel conflict. These results could be attributed to the tangible stakes in the Arab–Israel case that frequently touched upon human suffering and social matters while party politics, ideology and Cold War influence struggles were emphasized in the East–West confrontation.

sec.title: Multiple CPC modes
sec.p: Most CPC aspects varied within and across conflicts, so H1 on a uniform press coverage is rejected in favor of H2 on multiple CPCs. Differences were observed in the relative coverage of each conflict and its patterns over time, emphasis of crisis events at the expense of the wider conflict setting, contents and emotions covered in photos, as well as overall salience.

sec.title: Relative press coverage
sec.p: The relative coverage of the East–West conflict was almost three times higher than that of the Arab–Israel case, with 395 and 136 items respectively, befitting CPC of a superpower rivalry that is of major concern to NYT readership. These findings are especially meaningful given an identical number of 7 crises and a very similar number of about 70 crisis days in each conflict.5 This high CPC asymmetry is also evident in the number of front pages with no reference to crisis or conflict issues at all. Of the overall 145 crisis reporting days covered in the study, 40 days, or 28 percent of the narratives contained no mention of the crisis or conflict. But the distribution of non-coverage days was uneven in both conflicts, with a much higher 44 percent of all its crisis days in the Middle East crises, compared with a low of 10 percent in the East–West crises.

sec.title: Reporting patterns over time
sec.p: Findings in Figure 3 show that CPC over more than six decades follows mirror image trends for the two conflicts.

caption.p: Reporting patterns in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.p: If one draws an imaginary line connecting bar charts, the pattern in the Arab–Israel conflict resembles two repeated U-curves which involve a decrease in CPC frequency followed by an increase. In other words, there are two similar phases with a low of 7 percent coverage in the 1966 El-Samu and 1968 Karameh crises and a peak of 23 percent coverage at the intersection between both U-curves in the 1968 Beirut Airport crisis.

In the East–West conflict, the pattern seems to be two inverted U-curves: the coverage rate gradually increases from 13 percent in 1947 to the peak of 24 percent in the 1961 Bay of Pigs crisis, and slowly decreases thereafter to only 5 percent in 1984. These figures portray a non-monotonic relationship of reverse nature in CPC over time suggesting the interplay of diversity within and across conflicts.

sec.title: Photos as press coverage
sec.p: A picture is worth a thousand words, so the prevalence of text articles should not diminish the importance of photos and other graphic items (Griffin, 2004; Kennedy, 2008; Konstantinidou, 2008; Perlmutter, 2005; Perlmutter and Wagner, 2004; Zelizer, 2005). Findings in Figure 4A indicate that what the story photo narratives tell about the main object is rather similar: politicians and decision-makers appeared on the front pages more frequently than any other figure, followed by soldiers and militants as a second most frequent image.

caption.p: Photo coverage in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.p: However, some important differences are found across and within conflicts. To start with, CPC of the Middle East conflict contained fewer pictures of politicians and decision-makers than the East–West case: 35 percent and 49 percent in each, respectively, and portrayed emotional content which was almost absent in the East–West coverage. For example, images of families, refugees, bodies and coffins appeared in some 10 percent of the photos on the Middle East, in each category.

The analysis of the backgrounds of these pictures, presented in Figure 4B, also points to a difference between the two conflicts. In the Arab–Israel case, the destructive nature of violent encounters was captured by a disaster scene or ruins in 23 percent of the photos. By contrast, in the East–West confrontation, the most common background, in some 20 percent of the pictures, was a national/governmental building or no background at all. These findings may reflect on the more formal setting of the Cold War rivalry which involved fewer emotion-laden moments.

The emotional aspects embedded in photos point to further CPC differences, as detailed in Figure 4C. Though photos representing concern as a core emotion were the most frequent in both conflicts, with 28 percent and 21 percent, respectively, the next common emotion contained opposite feelings: sorrow, grief and despair in 24 percent of the Arab–Israel pictures, joy and happiness in 18 percent of the East–West ones.

On the whole, the photo coverage of the Arab–Israel case appears to be more diverse, hostile, violent and emotion-loaded than of the East–West case. These characteristics refute H1 regarding a single CPC mode and support H2 on high crises diversity coupled with multiple CPC modes.

sec.title: Crisis and conflict as topics
sec.p: Press narratives bring together crisis events and conflict backgrounds to create a colorful tapestry. Findings in Figures 5 and 6 show differences in the exposure of crisis and conflict topics further supporting H2 on CPC diversity.

caption.p: Topics in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.
Topic diversity in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.p: In the Arab-Israel case, a bulk 82 percent of all items focused on the crisis, while in the East–West conflict, a lower 59 percent did so. While it is reasonable that CPC in both conflicts preferred breaking news on crisis over the complex conflict developments, perhaps ideology-driven struggles tend to emphasize the conflict setting more than confrontations over other stakes.

When CPC combines reporting on crisis and conflict topics in the same item it creates a complex reporting style. Conflicts consist of multiple crises linked to one another by common issues. They encompass a wider range of hostile and cooperative interactions over a longer timeframe. Combined coverage of crisis and conflict paints a compound narrative, beyond stereotypes and mirror images. The presentation of multiple shades, inconsistencies and setbacks is likely to reflect crises diversity and result in a variety of CPC modes.

Indeed, as illustrated in Figure 7, in the Arab–Israel conflict, past and present broad narratives were provided jointly more often than in the East–West case, with 31 percent and 12 percent of the news items, respectively. At the same time, adding to CPC variety, reporting on conflict developments alone was infrequent in the Arab–Israel case, only 18 percent, but received high coverage, 40 percent, in the East–West confrontation. Within crises diversity was also evident during the mini-nuclear 1983 Able Archer events. Of the 43 items published on the NYT, all dealt with the ongoing Cold War but not a single article hinted that a crisis with peak gravity was in progress, an outstanding example of press unawareness.

caption.p: Joint crisis and conflict coverage in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.title: Salience
sec.p: Salience denotes the overall exposure an event receives in the media taking content and structure indicators into account. In accordance with most findings reported so far, salience varied within and between conflicts. Figure 8 illustrates a negative relationship between levels of coverage and salience in the CPC of the Arab–Israel conflict: as much as 40 percent, of the news contained low salience items on the NYT front page. With the move from low to mid-salience reporting, the share of items decreased to 33 percent and dropped even further to 27 percent in high salience.

caption.p: Overall salience in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts.

sec.p: This shows that CPC on the Arab–Israel conflict received relatively low priority in the entire news agenda in terms of location, headlines, picture coverage and overall number of items on the front page. These findings seem at odds with the literature expectation on high salience of all crises events and H1. CPC in the East–West confrontation revealed an opposite trend supporting the literature expectation with 67 percent of the news as high salience items.

Within conflict diversity in salience is presented in Figure 9. The 1996 Grapes of Wrath crisis reached the highest level of salience as 62 percent of its news items were given a central place on the front page agenda while the coverage of Karameh and Beirut Airport crises, both in 1968, was given the lowest salience among all other short crises in the Arab–Israel conflict.

caption.p: Salience diversity in the Arab–Israel conflict.
Salience diversity in the East–West conflict.

sec.p: By contrast, none of the crises in the East–West conflict were characterized by predominantly low salience, while high salience was found in four of the seven crises: the 1947 Marshal Plan, 1948 Communism in Czechoslovakia and 1961 Bay of Pigs with some 90 percent of articles in each at the peak of the news agenda, followed by 1983 Invasion of Grenada with 71 percent of the items.

Salience patterns also changed over time with lower but growing salience of news on the Arab–Israel conflict and higher but reducing salience of CPC on the East–West conflict. These results seem reasonable: the Cold War confrontation that involved superpower brinkmanship and dangers of escalation to nuclear war embodied consequences for the entire international community. As such, the confrontation received higher media attention than the more remote conflict in the Middle East. Furthermore, the NYT is both an international press agent and an American newspaper, so it naturally paid more attention to events and issues involving the USA. These patterns support H2 by crystallizing two distinct profiles of salience for each conflict and refute H1 on a uniform high salience irrespective of crises diversity for most CPC components.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study introduced the concept of CPC, outlined a theoretical framework to explain it and tested the uniform reporting mode assertion raised in communication literature, H1, and a rival hypothesis that emphasizes diversity in crisis attributes and their impact on multiple reporting modes, H2. Fourteen short crises in the Arab–Israel and East–West conflicts over six decades were analyzed showing that crises diversity within and across conflicts is associated with a variety of reporting modes. These results refute H1, the uniform reporting hypothesis, and support H2. The only two CPC aspects that supported H1 were the prominence of text over photos and the dominance of diplomatic and military issues. Five other CPC components supported H2. The Arab–Israel conflict, a regional confrontation composed of state and nonstate actors and dominated by violent hostilities, received limited and over time increasing coverage in the NYT. By contrast, the East–West conflict, a global confrontation mostly between superpowers over grave stakes was managed mainly without violence and received extensive but decreasing coverage over time. Compared to the East–West conflict, the CPC of the Arab–Israel case was also characterized by higher emphasis on crisis topics at the expense of conflict background, by more diverse, hostile and emotion-loaded photos and by lower overall salience. These differences in CPC may reflect the distinct profiles of the regional and global conflicts. The violent nature of the former was captured by the press, but its remoteness and low relevance to the American public moved the CPC to the margins of news agenda. The press also stressed the nonviolent but very dangerous nature of the East–West conflict, which received high priority in the entire news agenda. The conclusion is clear: CPC on different conflicts and crises varies considerably.

From the theoretical standpoint, the major implication from this conclusion is that CPC does not tone all crises in the same shades. It does not stress violence in cases where it is least dominant and does not emphasize peace when violence prevails. The press transforms the reality of a crisis to its readers without shaping it in a single way.

From the empirical perspective, the detection of a positive link between crisis attributes and multiple CPC modes in two ongoing conflicts may characterize other conflicts and reporting styles. The extent of empirical support for H1 or H2 in other cases still remains open. This means that policy makers and journalists should be aware of the overlap between their fields of activity and scholars should further investigate the interplay between international relations and communication variables. With more case studies and comparative analysis over many regions and longer timeframes, the generalizations derived from CPC research will become clearer.

The total of N = 571 includes 33 days of front pages with no reference to the crisis in the Arab–Israel conflict and only 7 days in the East–West conflict. The inter-coder reliability score on the variables included in the study was 0.89.
While globalization and technological advances should affect all CPC alike, diversity in findings indicates that coverage is more than a technical matter.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Hemda Ben-Yehuda, graduate program advisor at the Department of Political Studies, Bar-Ilan University, Israel, teaches international relations, methodology and simulations. She specializes in the Arab–Israel conflict, international terror, crisis research and the impact of nonstate actors on major international relations theories. Address: Department of Political Studies, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan 52900, Israel. [email: hemdaby@gmail.com]
